channel.title: Comments on: SQL Advent 2012 Day 7: Lack of constraints
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: sqlsister
item.dc:creator: sqlsister
item.description: I can always tell when a databse was designed for "Ease of development" as a priority rather than data integrity by whether the cvarious types of constraints are on the database. I have never yet seen a database with quality data that did not have at least some of these constraints.
item.content:encoded: I can always tell when a databse was designed for “Ease of development” as a priority rather than data integrity by whether the cvarious types of constraints are on the database. I have never yet seen a database with quality data that did not have at least some of these constraints.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: George correct, you are right about that, no need to pass in AAAAA to a zipcode column if you know it is has to be numeric
item.content:encoded: George correct, you are right about that, no need to pass in AAAAA to a zipcode column if you know it is has to be numeric

item.title: By: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.dc:creator: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.content:encoded:
Nice post!

“When I interview people”….

My response would have been check constraint AND validation on the front end. Why bother round-tripping it to the server just to be told you can’t do something? Check early and check often.
